Line 1: Line 1:
The '''Oklahoma City Museum of Art''' ('''OCMOA''') is a museum located in the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], [[USA]]. The museum features visiting exhibits; original selections from its own collection; a theater showing a variety of foreign, independent, and classic films each week; and a restaurant. OKCMOA is also home to the most comprehensive collection of [[Chihuly]] glass in the world including the fifty-five foot Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick Memorial Tower in the Museum's atrium.<ref>[http://www.okcmoa.com/exhibitions/dalechihuly-theexhibition Dale Chihuly: The Exhibition], Oklahoma City Museum Of Art.</ref>
The '''Oklahoma City Museum of Art''' ('''OCMOA''') is a museum located in the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], [[USA]]. The museum features visiting exhibits; original selections from its own collection; a theater showing a variety of foreign, independent, and classic films each week; and a restaurant. OKCMOA is also home to the most comprehensive collection of [[Chihuly]] glass in the world including the fifty-five foot Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick Memorial Tower in the Museum's atrium.<ref>[http://www.okcmoa.com/exhibitions/dalechihuly-theexhibition Dale Chihuly: The Exhibition], Oklahoma City Museum Of Art.</ref>
â
Accredited by the American Association of Museums, the Oklahoma City Museum of Art serves over 135,000 visitors annually from all fifty states and over thirty foreign countries and hosts special exhibitions drawn from throughout the world. The Museumâs collection covers a period of five centuries with strengths in American and European art of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and includes a comprehensive collection of glass sculpture by Dale Chihuly. The Museumâs Noble Theater is the regionâs premiere repertoire cinema, screening the finest international, independent, and classic films. Amenities include the Museum School, which offers classes for students of all ages as well as fall, winter, and summer art camps for youths; a teacher resource center; the Museum Store, Roof Terrace, and the Museum Cafe, whose cuisine is complemented by a full-service bar complete with cocktails, specialty coffees, and afternoon tea.
+
==References==
â  
{{reflist}}
{{reflist}}
â   â
Consisting of three floors of galleries, the Museum School, Noble Theater, and Museum Cafe, the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center is located in the Arts District of downtown Oklahoma City between Hudson and Walker Avenues on Couch Drive. The Museum in the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center opened in 2002 and was designed by Allen Brown Architects.
  â   â
Open to the public, the Library Resource Center is located on the mezzanine level of the Museum, the Library Resource Center features a collection of 7,500 non-circulating books and periodicals and provides circulating teaching aids for educators to use in their classrooms.
  â   â
Incorporating the original 1947 Centre Theatre as a preservation/reconstruction project, the 250-seat Noble Theater features a state-of-the-art projection system and is home to the Museumâs film program, which offers screenings year round, every Thursday through Sunday.
  â   â
Offering year-round, multiple-week classes and one-time workshops, Museum School is a creative outlet for children and adults. Sessions are presented in the Museumâs three classrooms, located on the ground floor of the east side of the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center, and incorporate learning in the galleries.
  â   â
The Oklahoma City Museum of Art has two lobbies, one at the atrium entrance to the buildingâs west, near Walker Avenue, and the second at the theater box office to the buildingâs east, near Hudson Avenue. Each features large-scale glass installations by Dale Chihuly.
  â   â
The Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick Memorial Tower, created by Dale Chihuly, was commissioned by the Oklahoma City Museum of Art in 1999. This monumental sculpture was created for the Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center atrium entrance in memory of the late Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick, a Museum founder.
  â   â
The Waterford Crystal Chandelier, one of two Chihuly Waterford Crystal Chandeliers in the world, is comprised of 203 individual blown lead crystal parts, each etched by Waterford artisans. The Chandelier is 9 ft., 7 inches in height, 5 ft., 5 inches in diameter, and weighs 2,000 pounds. It is mounted in the Noble Theater lobby. It may be viewed from the ground floor lobby or from the mezzanine lobby, which overlooks the theater lobby.
  â   â
The Roof Terrace is open to the public on Thursday evenings (MayâOctober) from 5 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. for Cocktails on the Skyline. The Roof Terrace is a gathering place for downtown workers, adventurous suburbanites, pre-concert and film goers, and the art crowd. Located atop the three-story Donald W. Reynolds Visual Arts Center, the Roof Terrace offers a spectacular view of downtown Oklahoma City. Thursday evening admission is $5 after 5 p.m. and always FREE FOR MEMBERS.
